Instructions.text: Press the round button beside the MINE stream box to open the Feed view. The stream going from the mine to the flotation circuit is called FEED. It has a certain grade of valuable metal, in our case copper.
Look at the graph. What is the copper grade of this mine?
True and considering you didn't touch this screen, what is the flow rate of the Feed Stream?
That's correct. Even if you have changed it, you could have guessed because flow rate is given by tons per hour.
Of course you are. Then tell me: after setting the Feed flow rate to 10 t/h, what is the flow rate of Concentrate Stream (the one which goes from the flotation bank to the bin)?

That's right. This means that from the 10 tons entering your flotation cell, 6 tons go to the Concentrate (which is the good stuff, that we can sell), while the other 4 tons go to the Tailings stream, which we didn't show just to simplify the process.
But going back to the Concentrate subject, as a flotation operator you want to make sure you are producing the right amount of concentrate according to your Feed flow rate.
After all, producing 6 tons of Concentrate out of 6 tons of Feed is very profitable, while producing 6 tons out of 600 hundred tons of Feed will make you bankrupt
You can check you are doing a good job by finding the CONCENTRATION RATIO. It represents the amount of tons you need to feed the cell in order to produce one ton of concentrate.
For example, if your concentrate flow rate is 2 t/h with a feed flow rate of 10 t/h, your concentration ratio is 5. The cell is producing one ton of concentrate with 5 tons of feed.

Let's put this knowledge into practice. Check the Concentrate graphs to make sure your Cu recovery is above 80%. Now tell me, what is the Concentrate Ratio of this process?

 Concentration ratio =
Feed flow rate / Concentrate flow rate

Yeah, kind of 2. More like 1,66666666667 to be more precise. Now press the circle in the mine icon and change the Feed flow rate to something like 20. Did the concentration ratio change? 

 Concentration ratio =
Feed flow rate / Concentrate flow rate
Exactly! Cells are usually designed to work with an optimal Concentration Ratio. In next lessons we will learn about other performance calculations
